title: Hagar and Ishmael
shortSummary: Genesis 16 recounts the story of Sarai giving her Egyptian maidservant Hagar to Abram to bear a child, resulting in the birth of Ishmael. This chapter highlights human impatience with God's promises and introduces Ishmael, whose descendants play a significant role in biblical history.
timeline: c. 2100 BC - Patriarchal period during Abram's sojourn in Canaan

keyCharacters.name: Sarai
keyCharacters.description: Abram's wife who, unable to bear children, gives her maid Hagar to Abram to conceive a child on her behalf.

keyCharacters.name: Abram
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch who obeys Sarai's request and fathers a child through Hagar, demonstrating human frailty in trusting God's timing.

keyCharacters.name: Hagar
keyCharacters.description: An Egyptian maidservant to Sarai who becomes pregnant by Abram and flees after mistreatment, but is comforted and instructed by the angel of the LORD.

keyCharacters.name: Angel of the LORD
keyCharacters.description: Divine messenger who finds Hagar in the wilderness, gives her instructions, and foretells the birth and future of her son Ishmael.

definitions.definition: A female servant or maidservant, often given to bear children on behalf of a barren wife in ancient Near Eastern culture.
To yield or be obedient to authority; here, Hagar is instructed to submit to Sarai’s authority despite her difficult circumstances.
A divine messenger who represents God’s presence and speaks with His authority, often delivering guidance or prophecy.
The son born to Abram and Hagar, whose name means 'God hears,' signifying God's awareness of Hagar’s affliction.

outline.heading: Sarai’s barrenness and plan
outline.description: Sarai, unable to have children, gives her maid Hagar to Abram to bear offspring, leading to tension and jealousy when Hagar conceives.

outline.heading: Hagar’s flight and encounter with God
outline.description: After Sarai mistreats her, Hagar flees but is met by the angel of the LORD who comforts her, commands her to return, and prophesies the birth and character of her son Ishmael.

outline.heading: Birth of Ishmael
outline.description: Hagar bears Abram a son, Ishmael, marking the fulfillment of God's promise to multiply Abram’s descendants, though not yet through Sarai.

application: Trust in God's timing rather than taking matters into your own hands when facing delays in His promises.
Respect and submit to God-ordained authority even in difficult personal circumstances, as Hagar was instructed to do.
Recognize that God sees and cares for those who suffer and are marginalized, as He did with Hagar.
Seek God's guidance and comfort in times of distress, trusting His plans for your life and future.

keyVerses.text: And the angel of the LORD said unto her, Behold, thou art with child, and shalt bear a son, and shalt call his name Ishmael; because the LORD hath heard thy affliction.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's personal care and awareness of Hagar’s suffering, affirming His involvement in human struggles.

keyVerses.text: And she called the name of the LORD that spake unto her, Thou God seest me: for she said, Have I also here looked after him that seeth me?
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the comforting truth that God sees and knows our circumstances, providing assurance to believers.

keyVerses.text: And the angel of the LORD said unto her, I will multiply thy seed exceedingly, that it shall not be numbered for multitude.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise to Hagar assures that her descendants will be numerous, demonstrating His faithfulness to His word.
